Yes, there have been several successful examples of interfaith dialogue in resolving conflicts around the world. Here are some examples:

1) Northern Ireland: After years of sectarian violence between Catholics and Protestants, there was a significant push towards interfaith dialogue in Northern Ireland. In 1998, the Good Friday Agreement was signed, partly due to the efforts of religious leaders from both sides to promote peace and reconciliation.

2) Bosnia and Herzegovina: The conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina was primarily driven by ethnic and religious divisions between Bosniaks, Serbs, and Croats. Interfaith dialogue initiatives, funded by international organizations like the European Union and the United Nations, helped to create spaces for people of different faiths to come together and discuss their differences. These efforts played a crucial role in building trust and laying the groundwork for the 1995 Dayton Agreement, which ended the war.

3) Middle East: The King Abdullah Bin Abdulaziz International Centre for Interreligious and Intercultural Dialogue based in Vienna, Austria is a globally recognized center that works on promoting interfaith and intercultural dialogue. Some of their initiatives include convening meetings including leaders of world religions to discuss critical issues affecting global citizens.

These are just a few examples of successful interfaith dialogue in resolving conflicts, and many more exist. While interfaith dialogue is not a panacea, it can play a crucial role in breaking down barriers and promoting understanding, essential components in resolving conflicts.
